source_span.text_evidence: Methane (CH4) is the second most relevant greenhouse gas (GHG) emitted by anthropogenic activities, representing more than 20% of the total worldwide GHG emissions. CH4 atmospheric concentration increases yearly at 0.2 e 1% its current tropospheric level exceeding preindustrial concentrations by z 150%. Anthropogenic emissions are mainly attributed to agriculture, livestock farming, waste management and energy production, which combined represent over 60% of the total CH4 emissions worldwide (European Environmental Agency, 2013; IPCC, 2013; United States Environmental Protection Agency, 2013). In addition, the impact of CH4 on climate change is z 34 times more detrimental than that of carbon dioxide (CO2) in a 100-y horizon (European Environmental Agency, 2013; IPCC, 2013; Scheutz et al., 2009). This scenario has caused a raised governmental and public awareness, which has promoted both the enforcement of multidisciplinary political initiatives and an increased research on CH4

source_span.text_evidence: The environmental conditions during culture enrichment, which ultimately determine its maximum speci /uniFB01 c biodegradation rate (qmax) and af /uniFB01 nity for the target pollutant (Ks), play a key role in the performance of bioreactors devoted to the treatment of methane emissions. The results obtained demonstrated that an increase in Cu 2 þ concentration from 0.05 to 25 m M increased the qmax and Ks of the communities enriched by a factor of z 3, even if the Cu 2 þ concentration did not seem to have an effect on the enzymatic ' copper switch ' and only pMMO was detected. Despite no clear effect of CH4 concentration on the population structure or on the biodegradation kinetics of the communities enriched was recorded at the two low CH4 concentrations studied (1 and 8%), a higher agitation rate increased the qmax by a factor of z 2.3 and Ks by a factor of z 3.1. Although emissions with CH4 concentrations above 20% are suitable for energy recovery by incineration or low-cost treatment by /uniFB02 aring, more than 50% of anthropogenic emissions contain CH4 at concentrations below 3% (old land /uniFB01 lls (0 e 20%), ventilated coal mines (0.1 e 1%), covered liquid manure storage tanks (0 e 3%), etc.)

The results obtained demonstrated that an increase in Cu 2 þ concentration from 0.05 to 25 m M increased the qmax and Ks of the communities enriched by a factor of z 3, even if the Cu 2 þ concentration did not seem to have an effect on the enzymatic ' copper switch ' and only pMMO was detected. Despite no clear effect of CH4 concentration on the population structure or on the biodegradation kinetics of the communities enriched was recorded at the two low CH4 concentrations studied (1 and 8%), a higher agitation rate increased the qmax by a factor of z 2.3 and Ks by a factor of z 3.1.

source_span.text_evidence: The present study aims at systematically elucidating the in /uniFB02 uence of CH4 and Cu 2 þ concentrations and of the effective CH4 supply rate (governed by the CH4 mass transfer to the microbial community) during the enrichment of MB communities on CH4 biodegradation kinetic parameters (qmax and Ks) and community structure in order to identify the optimum environmental factors supporting an ef /uniFB01 cient CH4 abatement and high biodiversity in full scale bioreactors.

Among them, CH4 gas concentration, O2 gas concentration and Cu 2 þ concentration in the aqueous media have been identi /uniFB01 ed as the main parameters in /uniFB02 uencing microbial CH4 abatement due to their key role on the nature and level of expression of CH4 monooxygenases (MMO), and therefore on the population structure of methane oxidizing bacteria (MB) (Li et al., 2014; Murrel et al., 2000; Semrau et al., 2010).

source_span.text_evidence: Copper is one of the most important factors controlling the relative expression of the two forms of monooxygenases in methanotrophs, sMMO and pMMO, and therefore in /uniFB02 uences the type of MB enriched (Murrel et al., 2000; Semrau et al., 2010). Previous enzymatic assays have shown that sMMO is synthesized at low Cu 2 þ concentrations (below 0.8 m M (Semrau et al., 2010)), while pmoA is always expressed at a signi /uniFB01 cant level regardless of the Cu 2 þ concentration and such expression increases at increasing copper concentrations (Hakemian and Rosenzweig, 2007; Murrel et al., 2000). However, other studies assessing the in /uniFB02 uence of copper on MB structure and MMO expression in natural ecosystems did not observe sMMO or type II MB at concentrations as low as 0.1 m M(Chen et al., 2007; Ho et al., 2013; Semrau et al., 2010). At this point it should be noted that despite some research provided insight into the role of copper using enzymatic and biochemistry studies, real scale operation is far more complex and requires the elucidation of the role of Cu 2 þ on the enzyme expression in natural mixed cultures.
